<ce:section-title id="sectitle0010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0010" view="all">A new metal-organic framework based on manganous (II) ions and a paddle wheel ligand, H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>[Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(BTB)] (Mn-BTB, HBTB = 1,3,5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene acid), was synthesized and structurally characterized. Mn-BTB was formed via self-assembly of one-dimensional (1D) helical chains interconnected through the carboxyl groups of the tripodal ligand HBTB to generate a 3D, extended network with a nanotube-like architecture and aperture size of 18.22 Å × 16.40 Å. The 2-fold self-interpenetration significantly enhanced the stability of the framework, although it minimized the empty space to some extent. Mn-BTB contains an accessible volume of 3143.6 Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> with a 47.1% porosity, which allowed the adsorption of large dye molecules. Cationic dyes (methylene blue (MB) and rhodamine B (RhB)) and an anionic dye (methyl orange (MO)) were examined for selective dye adsorption on Mn-BTB. Mn-BTB with an anionic skeleton was beneficial for the selective adsorption of cationic dyes.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new metal-organic framework based on manganous (II) ions and a paddle wheel ligand, H3[Mn3O3(BTB)] (Mn-BTB, HBTB=1,3,5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene acid), was synthesized and structurally characterized. Mn-BTB was formed via self-assembly of one-dimensional (1D) helical chains interconnected through the carboxyl groups of the tripodal ligand HBTB to generate a 3D, extended network with a nanotube-like architecture and aperture size of 18.22Å×16.40Å. The 2-fold self-interpenetration significantly enhanced the stability of the framework, although it minimized the empty space to some extent. Mn-BTB contains an accessible volume of 3143.6Å3 with a 47.1% porosity, which allowed the adsorption of large dye molecules. Cationic dyes (methylene blue (MB) and rhodamine B (RhB)) and an anionic dye (methyl orange (MO)) were examined for selective dye adsorption on Mn-BTB. Mn-BTB with an anionic skeleton was beneficial for the selective adsorption of cationic dyes.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Mn-BTB displayed a three-dimensional network with a negative charge skeleton.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Double-interpenetrating increased the stability of framework.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The high accessible pore is beneficial for adsorption large dye molecules.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Mn-BTB represented highly efficiency for selective adsorption of cationic dyes.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sectitle0030">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">In the past decade, following increasing industrial and technological progress, dye-wastewater has caused damage to global ecosystems and seriously threatened human health due to its toxicity. Therefore, efficient removal of dyes is extremely important and pressing []. At present, two main strategies have been extensively explored. One strategy is photocatalytic degradation [], which is an advanced oxidation process mostly carried out under light irradiation and based on the use of suitable photocatalytic materials. However, the photocatalytic activity of photocatalytic materials to degrade dyes present in water depends largely on their band gap, surface area, and electron–hole pairs generation []. The second strategy is to use an adsorption process by attracting dyes to the surface of a solid adsorbent and fixing them via physical or chemical bonds, and this strategy is recognized as the most efficient, promising and widely used fundamental approach in wastewater treatment due to its simplicity, viability and technical feasibility [].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Mn-BTB displayed a three-dimensional network with a negative charge skeleton.

Double-interpenetrating increased the stability of framework.

The high accessible pore is beneficial for adsorption large dye molecules.

Mn-BTB represented highly efficiency for selective adsorption of cationic dyes.

Introduction

In the past decade, following increasing industrial and technological progress, dye-wastewater has caused damage to global ecosystems and seriously threatened human health due to its toxicity. Therefore, efficient removal of dyes is extremely important and pressing []. At present, two main strategies have been extensively explored. One strategy is photocatalytic degradation [], which is an advanced oxidation process mostly carried out under light irradiation and based on the use of suitable photocatalytic materials. However, the photocatalytic activity of photocatalytic materials to degrade dyes present in water depends largely on their band gap, surface area, and electron-hole pairs generation []. The second strategy is to use an adsorption process by attracting dyes to the surface of a solid adsorbent and fixing them via physical or chemical bonds, and this strategy is recognized as the most efficient, promising and widely used fundamental approach in wastewater treatment due to its simplicity, viability and technical feasibility [].

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Various physical adsorbents have been developed, such as bamboo dust, peat, chitosan, lignite, fungi, moss, bark husk, chitin, coir pith, maize cob, pinewood sawdust, rice husk, and sago waste []. Activated carbon, with its large porous surface area, controllable pore structure, thermostability and low acid/base reactivity, has been widely used as a traditional adsorbent in the treatment of dye wastewater [,]. However, it is limited by its poor dye specificity due to its neutral framework and ineffectiveness for wastewater containing high concentrations of dye. Thus, it is necessary to find desirable chemical adsorption materials that can reduce pollutant organic dyes with a high efficiency and low loss and realize selective separation and recovery of raw materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Various physical adsorbents have been developed, such as bamboo dust, peat, chitosan, lignite, fungi, moss, bark husk, chitin, coir pith, maize cob, pinewood sawdust, rice husk, and sago waste []. Activated carbon, with its large porous surface area, controllable pore structure, thermostability and low acid/base reactivity, has been widely used as a traditional adsorbent in the treatment of dye wastewater [,]. However, it is limited by its poor dye specificity due to its neutral framework and ineffectiveness for wastewater containing high concentrations of dye. Thus, it is necessary to find desirable chemical adsorption materials that can reduce pollutant organic dyes with a high efficiency and low loss and realize selective separation and recovery of raw materials.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a typical class of crystalline materials with infinite network structures, possess the advantage of acting as molecular sieves for the selective adsorption of dyes because their pore size, shape, dimensionality, and chemical environment can be finely controlled by the judicious selection of their building blocks (i.e., metal and organic linker) []. The construction of discrete clustered metal carboxylate secondary building units (SBUs) is an effective and powerful synthetic method to produce highly porous MOFs [,]. Carboxylic acids are a popular choice for supramolecular synthons in the rational design of molecular crystals because of the directionality and predictability of their interactions. In particular, 1,3,5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTB), which is a tritopic linker, has been extensively used to construct more topologically different functional MOFs owing to its larger size (12.9 Å) and flexible coordination forms [].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a typical class of crystalline materials with infinite network structures, possess the advantage of acting as molecular sieves for the selective adsorption of dyes because their pore size, shape, dimensionality, and chemical environment can be finely controlled by the judicious selection of their building blocks (i.e., metal and organic linker) []. The construction of discrete clustered metal carboxylate secondary building units (SBUs) is an effective and powerful synthetic method to produce highly porous MOFs [,]. Carboxylic acids are a popular choice for supramolecular synthons in the rational design of molecular crystals because of the directionality and predictability of their interactions. In particular, 1,3,5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene (H3BTB), which is a tritopic linker, has been extensively used to construct more topologically different functional MOFs owing to its larger size (12.9Å) and flexible coordination forms [].

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">To match the dye molecular size and selectively adsorb cationic dyes, we designed and synthesized a new chiral metal–organic framework using Mn(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with an HBTB linker and <ce:small-caps>l</ce:small-caps>-pyrrolidine-2-yl-imidazole (PYI) as a chiral adduct. H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>[Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(BTB)O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·(named Mn-BTB) displayed a three-dimensional double-interpenetrating extended network with a negatively charged skeleton. Mn-BTB exhibited a high efficiency for the selective adsorption of cationic dyes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To match the dye molecular size and selectively adsorb cationic dyes, we designed and synthesized a new chiral metal-organic framework using Mn(OAc)2 with an HBTB linker and l-pyrrolidine-2-yl-imidazole (PYI) as a chiral adduct. H3[Mn3(BTB)O3]⋅(named Mn-BTB) displayed a three-dimensional double-interpenetrating extended network with a negatively charged skeleton. Mn-BTB exhibited a high efficiency for the selective adsorption of cationic dyes.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0035">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0040">Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">All solvents and reagents used in this study were reagent grade and used without further purification. H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTB and L-N-tert-butoxy-carbonyl-2-(imidazole)-1-pyrrolidine (L-BCIP) were prepared by the literature procedures [,].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

All solvents and reagents used in this study were reagent grade and used without further purification. H3BTB and L-N-tert-butoxy-carbonyl-2-(imidazole)-1-pyrrolidine (L-BCIP) were prepared by the literature procedures [,].

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Elemental analyses (EA) of C and H were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400-II CHNS/O analyser. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analyses of Mn were performed on a Jarrel-AshJ-A1100 spectrometer. IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker VERTEX 70 IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Diffuse reflectance spectra were collected at room temperature on a finely ground sample with a HITACHI U-4100 UV–Vis–NIR spectrometer equipped with a 60 mm diameter integrating sphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance instrument with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) in the angular range 2θ = 5-50° at 293 K.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Elemental analyses (EA) of C and H were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400-II CHNS/O analyser. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analyses of Mn were performed on a Jarrel-AshJ-A1100 spectrometer. IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker VERTEX 70 IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400cm-1. Diffuse reflectance spectra were collected at room temperature on a finely ground sample with a HITACHI U-4100 UV-Vis-NIR spectrometer equipped with a 60mm diameter integrating sphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance instrument with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5418Å) in the angular range 2θ=5-50° at 293K.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0045">Synthesis of Mn-BTB</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">A solution of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTB (0.020 g, 0.045 mmol), Mn(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (0.010 g, 0.60 mmol), imidazole (0.010 g, 0.60 mmol) and <ce:italic>L</ce:italic>-BCIP (0.060 g, 0.20 mmol) in 3 mL DMF was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel container, kept at 110 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. The obtained crystals were washed with DMF and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and then dried at room temperature in air (yield: 15.6 mg, 53% based on H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTB). EA and ICP calc'd (%) for C<ce:inf loc="post">27</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>: C 49.80, H 2.79, Mn 25.31; Found: C 49.92, H 2.76, Mn 25.38 for Mn-BTB.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Mn-BTB

A solution of H3BTB (0.020g, 0.045mmol), Mn(OAc)2 (0.010g, 0.60mmol), imidazole (0.010g, 0.60mmol) and L-BCIP (0.060g, 0.20mmol) in 3mL DMF was sealed in a 23mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel container, kept at 110°C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. The obtained crystals were washed with DMF and H2O and then dried at room temperature in air (yield: 15.6mg, 53% based on H3BTB). EA and ICP calc'd (%) for C27H18Mn3O9: C 49.80, H 2.79, Mn 25.31; Found: C 49.92, H 2.76, Mn 25.38 for Mn-BTB.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0050">Crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Mn-BTB data were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-K<ce:italic>α</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 0.71073 Å) using the SMART and SAINT programs [,]. Routine Lorentz polarization and multi-scan absorption corrections were applied to the intensity data. The structure was determined, and the heavy atoms were found by direct methods using the SHELXTL-97 program package []. All non-hydrogen atoms were anisotropically refined. Hydrogen atoms within the ligand backbones were geometrically fixed at their positions and allowed to move with the parent atoms. The atom site occupancy of O3 and O4 was constrained at 0.5. Hydrogen atoms within the ligand backbones were geometrically fixed at their positions and allowed to move with the parent atoms. Crystal data, experimental details, and refinement results are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. CCDC 1580387 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. The data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via <ce:inter-ref id="intref0010" xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif" xlink:type="simple">www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

Mn-BTB data were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα (λ=0.71073Å) using the SMART and SAINT programs [,]. Routine Lorentz polarization and multi-scan absorption corrections were applied to the intensity data. The structure was determined, and the heavy atoms were found by direct methods using the SHELXTL-97 program package []. All non-hydrogen atoms were anisotropically refined. Hydrogen atoms within the ligand backbones were geometrically fixed at their positions and allowed to move with the parent atoms. The atom site occupancy of O3 and O4 was constrained at 0.5. Hydrogen atoms within the ligand backbones were geometrically fixed at their positions and allowed to move with the parent atoms. Crystal data, experimental details, and refinement results are listed in  . CCDC 1580387 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. The data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0055">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0060">Structural description</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Mn-BTB was synthesized by a solvothermal reaction of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTB, Mn(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, imidazole and <ce:italic>L</ce:italic>-BCIP in DMF in a 53% yield. The single-crystal X-ray diffraction structural analysis revealed that Mn-BTB crystallizes in the space group <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>3<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. As illustrated in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>a, the asymmetric unit of Mn-BTB contains one crystallographically independent manganous ion, 1/3 BTB ligand and one oxygen atom distributed on two sites. Molecules of the chiral adduct were not found in the crystals. The crystallographically independent manganous ion adopts a distorted triangular prism geometry and coordinates with two carbonyl oxygen atoms from different BTB ligands and four half-occupied bridging oxygen atoms (b). Each independent carboxy group of the BTB ligands simultaneously coordinates with two manganous ions, forming one-dimensional Mn-O-Mn helical chains, and a pseudo 3<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> or 3<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> helix is constructed and expanded along the [001] direction with a length of 8.17 Å (c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structural description

Mn-BTB was synthesized by a solvothermal reaction of H3BTB, Mn(OAc)2, imidazole and L-BCIP in DMF in a 53% yield. The single-crystal X-ray diffraction structural analysis revealed that Mn-BTB crystallizes in the space group R3c. As illustrated in  a, the asymmetric unit of Mn-BTB contains one crystallographically independent manganous ion, 1/3 BTB ligand and one oxygen atom distributed on two sites. Molecules of the chiral adduct were not found in the crystals. The crystallographically independent manganous ion adopts a distorted triangular prism geometry and coordinates with two carbonyl oxygen atoms from different BTB ligands and four half-occupied bridging oxygen atoms (b). Each independent carboxy group of the BTB ligands simultaneously coordinates with two manganous ions, forming one-dimensional Mn-O-Mn helical chains, and a pseudo 31 or 32 helix is constructed and expanded along the [001] direction with a length of 8.17Å (c).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Mn-BTB possesses a rare chiral helical structure, and we suspect that the chiral <ce:italic>L</ce:italic>-BCIP plays an important role in the process of chiral helical formation, although the crystal data indicated an achiral nature (Flack parameter 0.5(2)). The three trifurcate carboxy groups of the BTB ligand link with the Mn-O-Mn helical chains to generate a 3D network with 1D hexagonal channels, which can be viewed as a nanotube-like architecture, and the size of the channel is 18.22 Å × 16.40 Å (measured between opposite atoms) viewed along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> direction (d and e).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Mn-BTB possesses a rare chiral helical structure, and we suspect that the chiral L-BCIP plays an important role in the process of chiral helical formation, although the crystal data indicated an achiral nature (Flack parameter 0.5(2)). The three trifurcate carboxy groups of the BTB ligand link with the Mn-O-Mn helical chains to generate a 3D network with 1D hexagonal channels, which can be viewed as a nanotube-like architecture, and the size of the channel is 18.22Å×16.40Å (measured between opposite atoms) viewed along the c direction (d and e).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Due to the repulsion between the hydrogen atoms of the central rings and those of the peripheral rings, BTB is nonplanar with an average dihedral angle between the central and peripheral rings of ca. 37° []. As expected, the use of BTB allows for two identical networks to interpenetrate, which is an arrangement that does not appear to be possible when all links are the same (related by symmetry) []. Two symmetrically related frameworks further perpendicularly interpenetrated each other to consolidate the robust structure (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>a–c), and the opening of the pores was reduced from 18.22 Å to 8.65 Å. As shown in d, the distance between adjacent BTB linkers is approximately 4.08 Å (measured between the carbon atoms of adjacent BTB ligands), which was reduced by almost half compared to the distance of the original nanochannels (8.17 Å). This indicates that strong CH···π interactions exist between the adjacent BTB ligands, and an impenetrable wall is constructed by the biphenyl rings of the BTB ligands if the van der Waals radii of the carbon atoms (1.7 Å) and hydrogen atoms (1.2 Å) are taken into account. Although interpenetration minimized the empty space, the stability of the frameworks was significantly enhanced. A number of MOFs based on H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTB with an interpenetrated network of hydrogen bonds and π–π bond weak interactions have been reported []; however, 3D, polyhedral frameworks introduced by self-interpenetration are rare [].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Due to the repulsion between the hydrogen atoms of the central rings and those of the peripheral rings, BTB is nonplanar with an average dihedral angle between the central and peripheral rings of ca. 37° []. As expected, the use of BTB allows for two identical networks to interpenetrate, which is an arrangement that does not appear to be possible when all links are the same (related by symmetry) []. Two symmetrically related frameworks further perpendicularly interpenetrated each other to consolidate the robust structure ( a-c), and the opening of the pores was reduced from 18.22Å to 8.65Å. As shown in d, the distance between adjacent BTB linkers is approximately 4.08Å (measured between the carbon atoms of adjacent BTB ligands), which was reduced by almost half compared to the distance of the original nanochannels (8.17Å). This indicates that strong CH⋅⋅⋅π interactions exist between the adjacent BTB ligands, and an impenetrable wall is constructed by the biphenyl rings of the BTB ligands if the van der Waals radii of the carbon atoms (1.7Å) and hydrogen atoms (1.2Å) are taken into account. Although interpenetration minimized the empty space, the stability of the frameworks was significantly enhanced. A number of MOFs based on H3BTB with an interpenetrated network of hydrogen bonds and π-π bond weak interactions have been reported []; however, 3D, polyhedral frameworks introduced by self-interpenetration are rare [].

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The permanent porosity of MN-BTB was confirmed by its N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption isotherm at 77 K. No sample activation was applied, and the as-synthesized sample was directly degassed at 80 °C for 48 h under a vacuum prior to the measurement (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>a). The BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) surface area and pore volume of Mn-BTB were calculated to be 5.089 m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 0.04175 cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively. A large pore size of 56.187 Å was also calculated. Calculations using PLATON showed that the accessible pores are approximately 3143.6 Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> [], which occupies approximately 47.1% of the volume of the whole crystal and suggests the possibility of adsorbing large dye molecules within the channels of Mn-BTB [,].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The permanent porosity of MN-BTB was confirmed by its N2 adsorption isotherm at 77K. No sample activation was applied, and the as-synthesized sample was directly degassed at 80°C for 48h under a vacuum prior to the measurement ( a). The BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) surface area and pore volume of Mn-BTB were calculated to be 5.089m2g-1 and 0.04175cm3g-1, respectively. A large pore size of 56.187Å was also calculated. Calculations using PLATON showed that the accessible pores are approximately 3143.6Å3 [], which occupies approximately 47.1% of the volume of the whole crystal and suggests the possibility of adsorbing large dye molecules within the channels of Mn-BTB [,].

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0065">IR spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The IR spectra of Mn-BTB were collected from solid samples pelletized with KBr in the range of 4000–400 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which are shown in b. The characteristic bands of the Mn–O vibrations in Mn-BTB are in the range of 1016–1109 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The signals at 1600, 1584, 1583 and 1400 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> correspond to the <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>C) bending vibration of the benzene ring, and the signals at 706–782 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> are assigned to the δ(=CH) bending vibration []. These characteristic vibration resonances confirm the existence of BTB ligands in Mn-BTB. In summary, the IR spectra results are consistent with those from X-ray diffraction.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
IR spectra

The IR spectra of Mn-BTB were collected from solid samples pelletized with KBr in the range of 4000-400cm-1, which are shown in b. The characteristic bands of the Mn-O vibrations in Mn-BTB are in the range of 1016-1109cm-1. The signals at 1600, 1584, 1583 and 1400cm-1 correspond to the ν(CC) bending vibration of the benzene ring, and the signals at 706-782cm-1 are assigned to the δ(=CH) bending vibration []. These characteristic vibration resonances confirm the existence of BTB ligands in Mn-BTB. In summary, the IR spectra results are consistent with those from X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0070">Dye adsorption properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">A high selectivity for different dye molecules is attractive for the treatment of wastewater as industrial development increases. To evaluate the adsorption performance of Mn-BTB for large dye molecules, we initially immersed the as-synthesized Mn-BTB in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O containing MB. The powder was filtered and dried in air, and then, its UV spectra were acquired. Solid state UV–vis absorption spectra of MN-BTB exhibited an intense absorption band centred at ∼300 nm, which is typically assignable to the n−π* and π−π* transitions of the aromatic organic electrons. As expected, a new broad band appeared after absorption. Accordingly, the absorption band at 680 nm was assigned to the n−π*transition of methylene blue (c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Dye adsorption properties

A high selectivity for different dye molecules is attractive for the treatment of wastewater as industrial development increases. To evaluate the adsorption performance of Mn-BTB for large dye molecules, we initially immersed the as-synthesized Mn-BTB in H2O containing MB. The powder was filtered and dried in air, and then, its UV spectra were acquired. Solid state UV-vis absorption spectra of MN-BTB exhibited an intense absorption band centred at ~300 nm, which is typically assignable to the n-π* and π-π* transitions of the aromatic organic electrons. As expected, a new broad band appeared after absorption. Accordingly, the absorption band at 680 nm was assigned to the n-π*transition of methylene blue (c).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0100" view="all">To evaluate the selectivity of Mn-BTB for large dye molecules, cationic dyes (methylene blue (MB) and rhodamine B (RhB)) and an anionic dye (methyl orange (MO)) (d) were used as typical organic pollutants for the adsorption experiments. Considering sorbate-sorbent interactions, the typical process is as follows: 4 mg of the compound was suspended in 10 mL of a 15 mg L<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> MB aqueous solution, 15 mg L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> MO aqueous solution or 12 mg L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> RhB aqueous solution. After ultrasonic dispersion in a beaker for 10 min, the solutions were magnetically stirred in the dark. At several time intervals, 4 mL of sample was removed, centrifuged several times to separate the new compound, and a clear solution was obtained for the UV–Vis analysis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the selectivity of Mn-BTB for large dye molecules, cationic dyes (methylene blue (MB) and rhodamine B (RhB)) and an anionic dye (methyl orange (MO)) (d) were used as typical organic pollutants for the adsorption experiments. Considering sorbate-sorbent interactions, the typical process is as follows: 4mg of the compound was suspended in 10mL of a 15mgL-1MB aqueous solution, 15mgL-1 MO aqueous solution or 12mgL-1RhB aqueous solution. After ultrasonic dispersion in a beaker for 10min, the solutions were magnetically stirred in the dark. At several time intervals, 4mL of sample was removed, centrifuged several times to separate the new compound, and a clear solution was obtained for the UV-Vis analysis.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0105" view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>a, the decrease in the absorption intensity at <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf> = 675 nm from 1.41 to 0.15 in 2 h indicates the absorption of MB molecules. The adsorption rate, defined as 1-C/C<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>, was 89.36%. Mn-BTB also exhibited rapid absorption properties for RhB (d). Approximately 20% of RhB was absorbed after 10 min in the dark, and then, no additional RhB was absorbed, even after approximately 2 h. This result might be due to the molecular size of RhB, which is larger than that of MB. Additionally, there was almost no colour change in the yellow MO solution, and the adsorption rate of MO was 2.57% (b). Due to the similar size of MB and MO, the selective adsorption of MB over MO must be ascribed to other factors. It is noteworthy that the maximum absorption peak of MO was steady, but those of both MB and RhB slightly redshifted by 8 nm and 5 nm, respectively. Generally, energy absorption, electron transfer and electrostatic interactions play an intrinsic role in the process of luminescence, i.e., electrostatic and π … π interactions between the catalyst and dye molecules []. Therefore, we speculate that there are some electrostatic interactions between the framework and cation dye molecules, which may be helpful for adsorption. Furthermore, a comparison between the Mn-BTB composite and some reported MOF absorbents is provided. For example, [Zn(phenDIB) (AOBTC)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] [] and [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(DMF) (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·9DMF [] can successfully separate cationic dyes such as MB rather than anionic MO molecules from mixed dye molecules in an aqueous solution with a high efficiency and selectivity, and the maximum MB adsorption capacities are 64.66 and 308 mg g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively. In contrast, Mn-BTB displayed a high selectivity but dissatisfactory adsorption capacity (33.8 mg g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>), which may be ascribed to the formation of an interpenetration structure, resulting in reduced accessible space.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in  a, the decrease in the absorption intensity at λ max=675nm from 1.41 to 0.15 in 2h indicates the absorption of MB molecules. The adsorption rate, defined as 1-C/C0, was 89.36%. Mn-BTB also exhibited rapid absorption properties for RhB (d). Approximately 20% of RhB was absorbed after 10min in the dark, and then, no additional RhB was absorbed, even after approximately 2h. This result might be due to the molecular size of RhB, which is larger than that of MB. Additionally, there was almost no colour change in the yellow MO solution, and the adsorption rate of MO was 2.57% (b). Due to the similar size of MB and MO, the selective adsorption of MB over MO must be ascribed to other factors. It is noteworthy that the maximum absorption peak of MO was steady, but those of both MB and RhB slightly redshifted by 8nm and 5nm, respectively. Generally, energy absorption, electron transfer and electrostatic interactions play an intrinsic role in the process of luminescence, i.e., electrostatic and π … π interactions between the catalyst and dye molecules []. Therefore, we speculate that there are some electrostatic interactions between the framework and cation dye molecules, which may be helpful for adsorption. Furthermore, a comparison between the Mn-BTB composite and some reported MOF absorbents is provided. For example, [Zn(phenDIB) (AOBTC)0.5] [] and [(CH3)2NH2]2[Cu3O(SO4)3Cu2L2(DMF) (H2O)]⋅9DMF [] can successfully separate cationic dyes such as MB rather than anionic MO molecules from mixed dye molecules in an aqueous solution with a high efficiency and selectivity, and the maximum MB adsorption capacities are 64.66 and 308mgg-1, respectively. In contrast, Mn-BTB displayed a high selectivity but dissatisfactory adsorption capacity (33.8mgg-1), which may be ascribed to the formation of an interpenetration structure, resulting in reduced accessible space.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0110" view="all">To verify the heterogeneity and reusability of the material, a simple filtration experiment was carried out to collect the catalyst after adsorption of MB (4 mg of Mn-BTB suspended in 10 mL of a 15 mg L<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> MB aqueous solution). Subsequently, the fast release process of the adsorbed MB was achieved by thoroughly washing the adsorbent with a dilute solution of DMF and absolute alcohol. The adsorbent Mn-BTB could be reused at least six times with a moderated loss in the adsorption capacity (from 89.36% to 87.22%). The IR spectra of the Mn-BTB bulky samples filtered from the catalytic reaction after six runs agreed well with the fresh samples, which indicated that the crystallinity was maintained (a).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To verify the heterogeneity and reusability of the material, a simple filtration experiment was carried out to collect the catalyst after adsorption of MB (4mg of Mn-BTB suspended in 10mL of a 15mgL-1MB aqueous solution). Subsequently, the fast release process of the adsorbed MB was achieved by thoroughly washing the adsorbent with a dilute solution of DMF and absolute alcohol. The adsorbent Mn-BTB could be reused at least six times with a moderated loss in the adsorption capacity (from 89.36% to 87.22%). The IR spectra of the Mn-BTB bulky samples filtered from the catalytic reaction after six runs agreed well with the fresh samples, which indicated that the crystallinity was maintained (a).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0115" view="all">To further confirm this speculation, other solutions with concentrations of 5 mg L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, 10 mg L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, 15 mg L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, 20 mg L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 25 mg L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> of MB were also prepared for parallel experiments, and a pseudo-first-order model and pseudo-second-order kinetic model were used to fit the experimental data (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>) [,]. As expected, high correlations between the experimental data for the adsorption of MB by the complex and the pseudo-second-order kinetic model were indicated by the R<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> values in the first half hour. These results strongly demonstrate that the great adsorption performance of Mn-BTB is due to electron transfer and chemical adsorption rather than the simple adsorption of single molecules with an increase in the MB concentration. All of the results illustrate that Mn-BTB has a high selectivity for the adsorption of MB from an aqueous solution due to electron transfer and chemical adsorption.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To further confirm this speculation, other solutions with concentrations of 5mgL-1, 10mgL-1, 15mgL-1, 20mgL-1 and 25mgL-1 of MB were also prepared for parallel experiments, and a pseudo-first-order model and pseudo-second-order kinetic model were used to fit the experimental data ( ) [,]. As expected, high correlations between the experimental data for the adsorption of MB by the complex and the pseudo-second-order kinetic model were indicated by the R2 values in the first half hour. These results strongly demonstrate that the great adsorption performance of Mn-BTB is due to electron transfer and chemical adsorption rather than the simple adsorption of single molecules with an increase in the MB concentration. All of the results illustrate that Mn-BTB has a high selectivity for the adsorption of MB from an aqueous solution due to electron transfer and chemical adsorption.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0075">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0120" view="all">In conclusion, we synthesized and characterized an unprecedented functionalized metal–organic framework based on 1,3,5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl) benzene and manganous salts. Mn-BTB features a unique, 3D framework constructed from distinct 1D, helical chains interconnected through the biphenyl groups of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTB to generate a 3D, interpenetrating, extended network with rare 1D, hexagonal, nanotube-like channels. The adsorption properties of Mn-BTB were investigated, and the manganous-based coordination polymer has a great performance for selectively adsorbing large dye molecules. This study provides further insights into the rational design of MOF-based functional materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we synthesized and characterized an unprecedented functionalized metal-organic framework based on 1,3,5-tris(4-carboxyphenyl) benzene and manganous salts. Mn-BTB features a unique, 3D framework constructed from distinct 1D, helical chains interconnected through the biphenyl groups of H3BTB to generate a 3D, interpenetrating, extended network with rare 1D, hexagonal, nanotube-like channels. The adsorption properties of Mn-BTB were investigated, and the manganous-based coordination polymer has a great performance for selectively adsorbing large dye molecules. This study provides further insights into the rational design of MOF-based functional materials.

cln_elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0045">Synthesis of Mn-BTB</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">A solution of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTB (0.020 g, 0.045 mmol), Mn(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (0.010 g, 0.60 mmol), imidazole (0.010 g, 0.60 mmol) and <ce:italic>L</ce:italic>-BCIP (0.060 g, 0.20 mmol) in 3 mL DMF was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel container, kept at 110 °C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. The obtained crystals were washed with DMF and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and then dried at room temperature in air (yield: 15.6 mg, 53% based on H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTB). EA and ICP calc'd (%) for C<ce:inf loc="post">27</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>: C 49.80, H 2.79, Mn 25.31; Found: C 49.92, H 2.76, Mn 25.38 for Mn-BTB.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Mn-BTB

A solution of H3BTB (0.020g, 0.045mmol), Mn(OAc)2 (0.010g, 0.60mmol), imidazole (0.010g, 0.60mmol) and L-BCIP (0.060g, 0.20mmol) in 3mL DMF was sealed in a 23mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel container, kept at 110°C for 3 days and then cooled to room temperature. The obtained crystals were washed with DMF and H2O and then dried at room temperature in air (yield: 15.6mg, 53% based on H3BTB). EA and ICP calc'd (%) for C27H18Mn3O9: C 49.80, H 2.79, Mn 25.31; Found: C 49.92, H 2.76, Mn 25.38 for Mn-BTB.

Calculations using PLATON showed that the accessible pores are approximately 3143.6 Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> [], which occupies approximately 47.1% of the volume of the whole crystal and suggests the possibility of adsorbing large dye molecules within the channels of Mn-BTB [,].</ce:para>

No sample activation was applied, and the as-synthesized sample was directly degassed at 80°C for 48h under a vacuum prior to the measurement ( a). The BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) surface area and pore volume of Mn-BTB were calculated to be 5.089m2g-1 and 0.04175cm3g-1, respectively. A large pore size of 56.187Å was also calculated. Calculations using PLATON showed that the accessible pores are approximately 3143.6Å3 [], which occupies approximately 47.1% of the volume of the whole crystal and suggests the possibility of adsorbing large dye molecules within the channels of Mn-BTB [,].

[b] wR₂ = [∑w²– Fc²)²/∑w(Fo²)²]¹/²; w = 1²(Fo²) + (xP)² + yP], P = (Fo² + 2Fc²)/3, where x = 0.0034, y = 340.4783 for Mn-BTB.

cln_elements.content:

(d) Representation of a hexagonal nanotube-like channel of Mn-BTB with dimensions of 18.22 Å × 16.40 Å viewed along the b axis. (e) The 3D network of MN-BTB with 1D, hexagonal, nanotube-like channels. (Colour code: MN, blue spheres; O, red spheres; C, yellow spheres; all the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

metadata.title: A mesoporous metal-organic framework: Potential advances in selective dye adsorption
